commit.message:
ksmbd: add payload_sz in ksmbd_share_config_response

If installing malicious ksmbd-tools, ksmbd.mountd can return invalid ipc
response to ksmbd kernel server. ksmbd should validate payload size of
ipc response from ksmbd.mountd to avoid memory overrun or
slab-out-of-bounds. This patch set payload_sz of payload_sz in
ksmbd_share_config_response to help ksmbd validate payload size of
KSMBD_EVENT_SHARE_CONFIG_RESPONSE ipc response

Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: add support for durable handles

As durable handles is supported in ksmbd kernel server, Add durable
handles parameter in ksmbd-tools. I would like to make it default
disable till it is stable.

Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: fix GCC parentheses warnings

GCC suggests clarifying order of evaluation.

Signed-off-by: Rosen Penev <rosenp@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: eliminate a use-after-free

Eliminate a use-after-free.

Signed-off-by: Robert Morris <rtm@ubuntu.lcs.mit.edu>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd: release 3.5.1 version

Major changes are:
 - Fix worker_init_sa_handler return type.
 - Don't add global default `read only = yes'.
   Shares are still read-only by default.

Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: don't add global default `read only = yes'

Since share parameters are applied in the non-descript hash table
iteration order, a share parameter should never undo the effect of an
another. For example, `force user' checks `share->force_gid' such that
it doesn't undo `force group' applied earlier. However, `read only'
does not follow this convention since it may undo `writeable' (and so
may its aliases). Since the hash table iteration order is non-descript,
this means that a share with `read only = yes' and `writeable = yes'
may or may not allow read-write access. With the 3.5.0 release, due to
the default global `read only = yes' added in commit 54d2a02, this
effect is always in play for shares that give `writeable = yes' (or
its aliases) instead of `read only = no'. Fix this by not adding
global default `read only = yes'.

Note that not setting `KSMBD_SHARE_FLAG_READONLY' for initial shares is
fine as it is only used to set `KSMBD_TREE_CONN_FLAG_READ_ONLY' which
itself is unused (and was broken until commit 3f88fbe).

Note also that the use of the IPC$ share is guarded by checking for
`KSMBD_SHARE_FLAG_PIPE'. So if it's given `KSMBD_SHARE_FLAG_WRITEABLE'
through the global section or a user-defined section, the code paths
for its use should not change.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: fix worker_init_sa_handler return type

The function doesn't return any errors, so switch it to void to silence
compiler warnings such as:
  mountd.c: In function 'worker_init_sa_handler':
  mountd.c:114:1: error: no return statement in function returning
		  non-void [-Werror=return-type]
    114 | }
        | ^

Signed-off-by: David Disseldorp <ddiss@suse.de>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: release 3.5.0 version

Major changes are:
 - Fix potencial NULL deference errors.
 - Improved and cleaned up incorrect Glib library usage.
 - Fix memleak and several bugs.
 - Replace std functions with glib ones.
 - update manpages.
 - Improve the validation of ksmbd-tools's files(subauth, pwddb, conf).
 - Increase the minimum glib version(2.40 -> 2.44)
 - Several clean-ups.
 - Add --list option to ksmbd.control.

Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: do full smbconf parse on ENOENT in adduser/addshare

Even if the smbconf file does not exist, we're still interested in the
`guest account' global parameter in adduser. In addshare the same would
be true for the `root directory' global parameter if it had a default
value. Do full smbconf parse even on ENOENT. Although now unnecessary,
add a check to prevent NULL deref of `global_conf.guest_account' in
__is_transient_user().

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: suppress warn_unused_result for freopen()

Some distros have freopen() with this attribute and also enable the
warning by default. Add an error path, which is practically never
reached, that suppresses the warning.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: fix typo in meson project name

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: make debug prints config reload friendly

After a config reload, a stale share is killed only after the last
client connected to it has disconnected. Thus, it is impossible to know
which instance of the share a `Kill share ...' message refers to when
viewing the logs. Fix this by printing, along with the share name, a
representation of the `struct ksmbd_share *' pointer. Do this for users
as well.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: fix memleak in rpc lsarpc

Fix memleak in rpc lsarpc.

Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: fix memleak in rpc samr

Atte reported memleak that found using valgrind.

Reported-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

Revert "ksmbd-tools: lookup both guest accounts on tree connect"

This reverts commit 12cfe708346b0de14f116edc2f449e79267d061a.

Reverting commit 0b87a71 has made this commit obsolete as the guest
account refcount bug no longer occurs.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

Revert "ksmbd-tools: release user when connection is removed"

This reverts commit 0b87a71a0d9ebb8f21f86e5355bad28a2e7d5e55.

The changes result in use-after-frees on tree disconnects of existing
connections after a config reload. This may be reproduced on Windows,
but not with smbclient or cifs-utils.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: remove redundant show_version()

All the tools/utilities print their version information identically, so
remove redundant show_version(). Use pr_info() instead of printf() as
that that convention is followed in control.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: fix two process_share_conf_kv() bugs

The `max connections' global parameter is `unsigned int', but the share
parameter one is `int'. Fix limiting the maximum value for the latter.
If KSMBD_SHARE_FLAG_INVALID worked (see commit 9891dbc), it would be
good to check that `comment' is valid UTF-8, so add the check.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: add --list to control

Add `--list' option to control. When the manager receives SIGUSR1, it
passes it to the worker, and then opens the named pipe created by the
sender process. The manager creates a pipe before forking the worker,
with the worker then using the write end to send the config listing to
the manager when signalled to. As for marking the end of a listing, the
worker can't close the write end, as it would prevent further listings,
but will instead send SIGUSR1 back to the manager. Then, the manager
closes the write end of the named pipe, having written to it the
listing received from the worker.

Note that unlike in addshare and adduser, the share and user tables see
concurrent use in mountd and as such we cannot do an ordered write of
the listing without allocs. For now, the shares are listed in the
nondescript hash table iteration order.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: improve mountd daemonization and signal handling

Currently, when mountd daemonizes, the PID file is *not* created before
the mountd manager parent exits. This is a problem for service managers
since they assume that the mountd manager parent exiting with status 0
means that the mountd manager PID is in the PID file. This behavior is
not possible with daemon(3). Drop it and do a service-manager-friendly
daemonization. The mountd manager signals successful daemonization by
sending the parent SIGUSR1. Note that we still do *not* perform the
double-fork trick for never acquiring a controlling terminal.

Currently, mountd also has problems regarding signal handling. Namely,
the handler mostly calls functions which are not async-signal-safe.
Also, the signal-block and signal-ignore masks are inherited from the
parent and are not reset. There is also the issue of the thread signal
mask as the helper thread spawned by g_thread_pool_new() inherits it
and passes it down to threads spawned with g_thread_pool_push().
Address these issues by only calling async-signal-safe functions in the
handler, resetting the signal-block and signal-ignore masks, and
blocking the signals before spawning the helper thread, respectively.
Also, block the signals when accessing global data accessed also in the
handler, so if the need arises, *some* not async-signal-safe functions
may be called.

Note that using pthread_sigmask() over sigprocmask() is a matter of
picking your poison, the use of the former assumes that GLib threads
are POSIX threads (sane) while the use of the latter assumes that it
only modifies the thread signal mask (sane).

Also, note that we now use select() in ipc_process_event() so a config
reload takes effect *immediately* rather than at the next IPC event.
We remove the KSMBD_SHOULD_RELOAD_CONFIG flag only on success.

Finally, note that the use of sigaction() with SA_NOCLDWAIT assumes
that the child still sends SIGCHLD to the parent, which is a Linuxism.
Alternatively, each sigwaitinfo() for SIGCHLD could be followed by a
waitpid() so as to prevent zombies.

With the above changes, an abort() in a GThreadPool thread (e.g. due to
GLib OoM) no longer results in a variety of use-after-frees. Also,
neither a segfault nor an initial pwddb/smbconf parse fail result in a
worker process restart.

As for other changes, don't zero `global_conf' with memset() since it
it is already zeroed and we do not depend on the padding being zero.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: improve lock file handling

Improve lock file validation and move file parsing to the config parser
altogether. Drop the use of advisory locking since it is in practice
sufficient to just check the PID by sending it the null signal. Also,
don't remove the lock file on exit as that is racy and the job of the
service manager.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: don't use fixed buffer size in control

Don't hardcode size of buffer used for reading sysfs attributes in
control. Also, remove the extra newlines from the `-c' and `-d' prints,
improve error paths, and print usage page if only `-v' is given.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: introduce load_config() and remove_config()

Since set_conf_contents() always sets the file perms to 0640, there are
few situations where, *when* using the utilities, the file is readable
but not writable. As such, the only significant use case remaining for
test_file_access() is checking whether the file can be created. Remove
test_file_access() and do the check with set_conf_contents(). Also, do
it in the config parser since there is already a precedent for it.

Introduce load_config() and remove_config() that perform the proper
per-tool resource load and final release, respectively.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: make *_init() and *_destroy() idempotent

Prevent double-frees if *_destroy() is called twice without a
corresponding *_init() in between. Conversely, prevent leaks in
*_init(). Since usm_init(), shm_init(), sm_init(), and wp_init()
do not return on error, rather they abort, change them accordingly.
As for other *_init(), they all see use only in the worker process
init, which restarts on abort, so have them abort on error as well.

Curiously, ipc_init() and spnego_init() do cleanup on error, with the
latter doing so resulting in a later double-free with spnego_destroy()
if `kerberos keytab file' or `kerberos service name' is given. Although
the above changes fix this, only do cleanup later in *_destroy(). In
ipc_destroy(), remove ipc_ksmbd_shutting_down() as it does nothing and
properly guard genl_unregister_family().

Also, note that g_strdup(NULL) is a no-op, nl_socket_modify_cb() cannot
fail with the current args, and due to worker restart there is no need
to wait for the kernel module in ipc_init().

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: don't init and clear static GRWLocks

There is no need to call g_rw_lock_init() and g_rw_lock_clear() for
statically allocated GRWLocks.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: introduce set_tool_main() and get_tool_name()

Remove set_logger_app_name() and get_logger_app_name() and introduce
set_tool_main() and get_tool_name(). The tool name is now the logger
app name. The TOOL_IS_* macros can be used to check which tool is
executing common code that is shared by the tools or utilities.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: don't use fixed printf format for subauth file write

Don't hardcode the number of subauths in the printf format.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: reduce GLibby typing in session management

Remove superfluous GLib types in session management by doing function
pointer casts instead. Also, remove __free_func() by using
g_list_free_full() instead.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: reduce GLibby typing in share management

Remove superfluous GLib types in share management by doing function
pointer casts instead.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>

ksmbd-tools: introduce ghash_for_each*()

The use of g_hash_table_foreach*() functions leads to excessive
indirection and either type casts or function pointer casts. Instead,
introduce ghash_for_each*() macros which utilize GHashTableIter.

Signed-off-by: Atte Heikkilä <atteh.mailbox@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Namjae Jeon <linkinjeon@kernel.org>
